snippet: Despite striking in a region receiving considerable development aid, nodding disease has confused doctors in Uganda, where it has killed more than 200 children since January.
abstract: People of Ojuru, Uganda, are turning to traditional healers for nodding disease, a mysterious ailment that has stalked the brains and nervous systems of thousands of children in this part of Africa; debilitating disease stunts growth, causes mental retardation and sets off sudden seizures; no one knows what causes it, and it appears to attack only children; since January, more than 200 Ugandan children have died from the disease.
lead_paragraph: Despite striking in a region receiving considerable development aid, nodding disease has confused doctors in Uganda, where it has killed more than 200 children since January.

headline.seo: Ugandans Turn to Healers for Mystery Disease
headline.main: Desperate Ugandans Seek Makeshift Healers as Mysterious Illness Strikes Young
